Deftux
Feature Stub

Recent:

What it is: Affinity Photo is a photo editing app from Serif. When you select tools, a small tooltip at the bottom tells you how to use it.

Why it’s good: Photo editing is pretty obviously not a new space. Anytime new software is introduce, its immediately compared to Photoshop and sometimes Pixelmator. I don’t particularly enjoy recalling the gruelling climb to become proficient in Photoshop. I wouldn’t want to do it again.

The reason that these directions are so brilliant is because of their economy. They tell you how different click patterns will behave. They tell you how modifier keys will change the behavior. The microcopy is explanatory, but short.

What it is: When you are picking projects, Toggl also gives you a way to add new clients and projects as part of the workflow.

Why it’s good: Nobody likes being told “Hey, you’re in the wrong part of the app.” This flow is particularly effective because it accomodates a user’s thought process - instead of giving an empty state “nothing matched your search” it takes the data of your search and uses it constructively. It turns a “no” into a “yes, and” so I don’t have to jump over into the projects section to enter in the new thing I’m working on.

What it is: Duolingo’s Android Wear App gives you a series of 10 flashcards to practice the language you are learning.

Why it’s good: I haven’t dealt with a lot of good android wear apps yet. Media players and Hangouts aside, most of the functionality has been bizzare and useless.

This app is good because it doesn’t try too hard. It’s very simple functionally and it doesn’t try to force me into any awkward interfaces. (everything is a non local tap or a big swipe) Above all, the value of it makes total sense to me. Have 30 seconds? Review some flash cards!

What it is: In the bathrooms in rest stops, VDOT puts signs above the mirrors… but in reverse!

Why it’s good: Clever details draw attention. This sign is utterly unremarkable, except for the fact that VDOT thought of a way to put it in my field of vision without blocking the mirrors. It only works with simplicity though, so they wisely didn’t overdo the messaging.

What it is: Prune is an an atmospheric and haunting game about growing your tree to reach light. The animations are used instead of instructions to indicate to the user how to navigate.

Why it’s good: Believe it or not, I had never considered how I would move back and forth between the categories of levels before making this gif. The animation as you change worlds led me to think I could probably just pan back and forth, and behold, I can!

Prune has a remarkable economy of text, (they don’t want to violate the spare environment) so it is a wonderful example of visual explanation. Each state that you can arrive to has an entrance and an exit animation that orients you to where you are and what is available to you.
